item.question: Which of the following websites are good resources for known security problems, and for obtaining patches and updates for vulnerable applications?
item.hint: Sorry, no hint for this one. You either know 'em or you don't.

item.question:
On a system with a single network interface you are asked to make sure remotely logged in users are disconnected.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: The question does not tell you if running processes may be stopped as well. As you are assumed to be a good sysadmin you should pick the option that will minimize system disruption. Therefore, you should try to only disconnect the users and not bring down anything that can be kept running. To make it clear, shutting down is not considered a viable option nor switching to single user mode. Asking users politely to go away or killing them will probably not work.

item.question: Your company policy requires employees to change their password once every 6 months and demands that a user-account will be disabled if the user fails to change her password within a grace period of 30 days. How would you accomplish this?
item.hint: To manipulate password ageing information the file <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font> must be edited. Although you can do this using a normal text-editor it is wise to use a dedicated command for this.

item.question: Based on what the above exhibit shows, which of the following statements is TRUE?
item.choice: The script will run daily to calculate the network routes.
The <font face="monospace">renice</font>-command will renice the previous command <font face="monospace">echo</font>.
The command <font face="monospace">calculateroutes</font> will be executed with the nice value <font face="monospace">19</font>.
The script will print the message “Starting route-calculation on” followed by the current date and time.
item.correct_answer: The command <font face="monospace">calculateroutes</font> will be executed with the nice value <font face="monospace">19</font>.
The script will print the message “Starting route-calculation on” followed by the current date and time.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the correct order in which the BASH shell will search for a command?
item.hint: When you provide a pathname, i.e. the commandname contains a forward slash, you tell the shell exactly where to find the command. Therefore it does not have to search for it in this case. When you only provide the commandname (i.e. without a forward slash) the shell will search for a command with the given name. This can be either a builtin (shell function) or an executable on a filesystem.

item.question: How would you temporarily disable a user's login account?
item.choice: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
By setting the user's shell to <font face="monospace">/usr/sbin/nologin</font> and changing it back to the default shell when the account needs to be enabled again.
Removing the user's entry in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
Deleting the user account and recreate it afterwards.
item.correct_answer: By changing the user's password and changing it back when the account needs to be enabled again.
item.hint: Locking a user's account can be accomplished using the command <font face="monospace">passwd</font> with the option <font face="monospace">-l</font>. The way it locks an account is by simplying putting a <font face="monospace">!</font> or <font face="monospace">*</font> in front of the hashed password string in <font face="monospace">/etc/shadow</font>. This will result in an invalid hash for which no password will ever match. This effectively locks out a user from the system. Note that, if the user is currently logged in he or she will not be affected as long as he or she does not logout.

item.question: Which command will show the contents of all files side-by-side?
item.hint: The question asks for all files. This means you can discard two choices immediately. As you want the contents of all files side-by-side <font face="monospace">paste</font> will need to know about the different files. Passing text through standard input will discard this information.

item.question: Your department decided to change the Gnome Display Manager's greeting. Which configuration file should you edit?
item.hint: This is a nasty question. The default location for configuration files is under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>. However, this does not apply for the Gnome display manager. So you are left with either <font face="monospace">/opt</font> or <font face="monospace">/usr</font> as possible choices. As you know that <font face="monospace">/opt</font> is rarely used under Linux your best bet would be to go for <font face="monospace">/usr</font>.

item.question: Which of the following tools allows you to protect the system from normal users creating a denial of service using a so-called fork bomb?
item.hint: A fork bomb is a simple program that creates many processes continuously. To protect a system against a fork bomb you will need to limit the amount of processes a single user may run simultaneously.

item.question: Alice calls to complain that she is not allowed to create a crontab entry. You setup a default deny for crontab usage. Which file would you most likely need to edit to give her access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Consider above exhibit. Which of the following statements if true?
item.choice: The column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated and set equal to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">books</font> will be updated where <font face="monospace">title</font> equals <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
The table <font face="monospace">title</font> will be updated and all rows in the column <font face="monospace">books</font> will be set to <font face="monospace">linux</font>.
All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.
item.correct_answer: All rows will be updated in the table <font face="monospace">books</font>.
item.hint: The statement comes from SQL. The UPDATE will modify the cells for each rows in the column specified by SET.

item.question: Which of the following lines would you find in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font>?
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/nsswitch.conf</font> is used by the resolver library to check what and in what order it should consult to resolve a hostname to an IP address. Usually this is first the <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts</font> and second a remote DNS server.

item.question: Which <font face="monospace">syslog</font> facility is used by the <font face="monospace">cron</font> daemon?
item.hint: Sometimes the facility matches the name of the daemon.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines will stop all running processes with the name <font face="monospace">catchme</font>? (Select two)
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">ps</font> will show a header which will not contain valid input for the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command. Also, be sure to pick TWO answers. Any other amount is incorrect.

item.question: The ______ command is used to print out the current date and time on the system.
item.hint: The question does not state if you should print the hardware or system time. Therefore, you may assume both are correct.

item.question: You are running an IPv6 network and a system on that network needs to sent a packet to another IPv4 only system with IPv4 address <font face="monospace">80.113.6.236</font>. Provide the IPv4 mapped IPv6 address.
item.hint: There are many ways to provide the asked address. However, you should provide the answer with the minimal amount of characters possible. Hence, reduce as much zero's as possible by <font face="monospace">::</font>.

item.question: Which tool allows you to create a new public/private keypair for <font face="monospace">ssh</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following lines from <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> indicates a font server must be used?
item.hint: A font server is accessed through a communication service such as an IP network or Unix domain sockets. When you access a font server through a domain socket you need to specify <font face="monospace">unix</font> with the correct port number.

item.question: Which of the following configuration files is used to configure access through XDMCP for remote X11 clients?
item.hint: In this case the hint is in the question ;)............ access.\nThe file xdm.conf is the main configuration file and usually specifies other files to hold specific configuration information. The Xsession is used by the program Xsession that will run as the user's session and setup the user's X environment. The file Xresources usually contains parameters for X widgets, such as color, size, etc.

item.question: Considering a Debian linux system. What are the default permissions for the <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> file?
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> must be readable by everyone.

item.question: Which of the following fields are required in the <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> file for a user account? (Choose all that apply)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: If you want to execute a script called <font face="monospace">findguru</font> and want to disable the variable <font face="monospace">GURU</font> only for the current execution of the script, which of the following commandlines is correct?
item.hint: To setup the environment for a program you use the command <font face="monospace">env</font>.

item.question: Your senior system administrator asked you to edit the <font face="monospace">/etc/inetd.conf</font> file in order to disable the time service. After doing so, what would be the next thing to do?
item.choice: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and kill it with <font face="monospace">kill -15</font>.
item.correct_answer: Find the PID of <font face="monospace">inetd</font> and send it a <font face="monospace">SIGHUP</font>.
item.hint: Many daemons interpret the hangup signal as restarting and/or reloading the configuration file.

item.question: The user bob complains that he cannot access his email. In which directory would you look to see if there is any delivered email for him?
item.hint: The default location for queues is under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>. In computer science, spool refers to the process of placing data in a temporary working area for another program to process. Each system that requires a spool creates its own directory under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>, usually named after the system that uses it.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What best describes the above output?
item.choice: The program <font face="monospace">xeyes</font> failed to execute.
item.hint: Every program that stops will return a so called exit code. This code tells the system if an error occured or not. The shell will keep the error code of the last command executed in the variable <font face="monospace">?</font>.

item.question:
A user guru0 complains that he can not execute a script called makemeroot as shown above.
Which permission is needed to allow the user to execute the script?
item.hint: The question mentions that the command is a script. A script needs to be interpreted by another program. Therefore it is not the script itself that is executed. It only contains the command lines that must be executed.

item.question: In order to bypass print filters using lpr, which of following switches should be used:
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: A possible problem with running scripts is that a mistake can lead to an explosure of new processes. This may result in the system becoming unresponsive. How can you minimize the impact of these mistakes?
item.choice: Include the line <font face="monospace">ulimit -u 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/profile</font>.
Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Include the line <font face="monospace">* soft nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
Find the user who wrote the script and have a good talk about programming practices
item.correct_answer: Include the line <font face="monospace">* hard nproc 1024</font> in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/security/limits.conf</font>
item.hint: When a process reaches its soft limit it will be denied any more of the limited resource. However, a user is allowed to increase the soft limit up to the hard limit. You can also think of it as the soft limit being a default and the hard limit being the absolute maximum.

item.question:
Consider the following partial output from a linux system configuration file.
Which of the following files includes above output?
item.hint: The file shows service names with their associated portnumbers as assigned by IANA.

item.question: You have just added the above line to your <font face="monospace">syslog.conf</font> file. But, kernel messages are not being sent to the file <font face="monospace">/var/log/kernel.info</font>. What is most likely the problem?
item.choice: You made a syntax error in the file <font face="monospace">syslog.conf</font>
You should have changed the file <font face="monospace">rsyslog.conf</font>
You forgot to restart the syslog daemon
You made a mistake. The facility <font face="monospace">kern</font> should be <font face="monospace">kernel</font>.
item.correct_answer: You forgot to restart the syslog daemon
item.hint: Most daemons do not automatically detect configuration changes. Usually you will use an init-script to have the daemon reload its configuration file or restart.

item.question: Which configuration file would you edit to change the default options for ssh sessions to other machines?
item.hint: When a command name ends at the letter <font face="monospace">d</font> it usually refers to daemon. Therefore, <font face="monospace">sshd</font> refers to the daemon of the ssh service. The client program has the same name but without the <font face="monospace">d</font> at the end.

item.question: Which of the following commands will resolve a hostname to an ip-address? (Choose all correct answers)
item.hint: The question is not which command would you use to resolve a hostname to an ip-address. But which commands do hostname resolving. This means that programs that do accept hostnames and resolve these to ip-addresses to fulfill their task are also correct answers.

item.question: Which of the following services are usually NOT protected via TCP wrappers?
item.hint: Some programs have builtin support for TCP wrappers, others are protected as they are started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. Some don't use TCP wrappers at all and have their own methods for access control. The Apache webserver is never started by <font face="monospace">inetd</font> or <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.

item.question: To print a list of mails currently in the queue, which command would you use?
item.hint: We are talking about mail, not print jobs

item.question: What can you do to recover a lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA authentication key?
item.choice: Decrypt the authentication key with gpg.
A lost passphrase cannot be recovered.
Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.correct_answer: Use a brute force method to guess the correct passphrase
item.hint: A lost passphrase for a DSA or RSA key cannot be retrieved using somekind of decryption technique. You can however use a cryptanalysis method to try to guess the lost passphrase. If this will be succesful during your lifetime depends on the chosen passphrase and its complexity.

item.question:
Complete the following command to make sure no one, except root, can log in.
touch /etc/
item.hint: Only provide the text that should follow the given command. Do not retype the complete command.

item.question: Which of the following lines would you expect to see in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/hosts.allow</font>?
item.hint: The format of the <font face="monospace">hosts.allow</font> file is service name (proces name) followed by the access control rule or rules.

item.question: Considering below choices. What key combination can be used to force restarting the X server?
item.hint: Most Linux distributions running HAL have not enabled a key combination to restart the X server. Therefore, the correct answer may not even work on your system. However, in the past, all X servers would respond in the same manner to the key combination (<font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> option <font face="monospace">DontZap</font>). The question is about those X servers and the key combination that would make them restart.

item.question: You want to copy all files in the current directory to the directory <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>. Which of the following scripts will copy all regular files without generating any file-permission errors knowing that you have write permissions for <font face="monospace">/tmp/guru</font>?
item.hint: We went a little overboard on this question and provided many choices with subtle differences. Read all choices very carefully and pay good attention to the if-statements.

item.question: From the following list of names select TWO that provide print-services on a linux system.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Using <font face="monospace">xdm</font> users may create and edit a configuration file in their home directory that can tell the X window system what window manager they wish to start when they log in. Which file is that?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You just started your new job as sysadmin and stumble upon a system that still uses passwords in <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. Which of the following tools allows you to convert the password system to the “shadowed password file”?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Your logfiles are getting very large and you decide to exclude all log messages of a given logging facility. Which priority should you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You need to print 10 copies of the document <font face="monospace">atcomputing.txt</font>. Which of the following commands would you use?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">lpr</font> accepts a document to print through standard input or can read a document itself. Remember that <font face="monospace">></font> will write the standard output to a file. Also note that often a <font face="monospace">#</font> is interpreted as amount.

item.question: Which two daemons will start services on demand?
item.hint: This question is about the concept of a super daemon. This is a daemon that will listen to network connections on behalf of other daemons. Whenever a connection is made the corresponding daemon is started by the super daemon to handle the network session. The benefit is that you only need one daemon running at all times and the super daemon can connect standard input and output to the network. The latter allows you to write a simple shell script as a network daemon.

item.question: Which of the following commands allows you to print the file <font face="monospace">linux.txt</font> and delete the file afterwards?
item.hint: Most linux commands try to make the options self explaining as much as possible. Thus, deletion is usually connected to an option <font face="monospace">-r</font> or <font face="monospace">-d</font>. Now you got a 50/50 chance of guessing the right answer. Although the <font face="monospace">--remove</font> might get you out of balance.

item.question: Consider the above command. What does the argument <font face="monospace">-s</font> do?
item.choice: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Show the account settings for <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
Nothing, as <font face="monospace">useradd</font> does not know about an option <font face="monospace">-s</font>
item.correct_answer: Specify the default shell for the user <font face="monospace">guru1</font>
item.hint: Most programs try to make the options as intuitive as possible. They usually are the first letter of the spelled out option name.

item.question: Which of the following can you use to disable the system bell sound?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You use above <font face="monospace">enscript</font> command regularly to print out a nice formatted version of your scripts. How can you convert above command easily into a single word command and still allows you to specify one or more filenames as command line arguments?
item.choice: Download the source code for <font face="monospace">enscript</font>, modify it to make my options default, compile and install it.
Post a bug report asking the developers to make my options the default.
item.hint: The question is about an easy way.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. When the user logs in and starts a login shell what will be the value of the variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: All mentioned files in the exhibit are correct. You will need to know which files are read in which order when the user starts a login shell.

item.question:
What syslog facility represents user authentication processes?
(Select all correct answers)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the network does not work. You remember adding an extra network-card to her machine yesterday and did not test the new setup. You have a feeling that the network cards might be conflicting. Which file would you check?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want syslog to sent all kernel messages with priority critical to all terminal-screens. Which of the following syslog configuration entries would you use?
item.hint: Most programs use the asterisk (<font face="monospace">*</font>) to specify all.

item.question: You just installed a non-multiboot Linux system. What is the recommended time for the hardware clock?
item.choice: There is no recommendation concerning the hardware clock.
item.hint: On a computer system that needs to keep accurate time you will always encounter a Real Time Clock also known as the hardware clock. The Linux kernel however will not use the real time clock directly but will maintain a so called system clock. This system clock is set to UTC. During system startup the system clock is synchronized with the hardware clock and vice versa during the shutdown procedure. If the hardware clock is not in UTC, the kernel will convert the real time to UTC to be used in the system clock.

item.question: Consider the above exhibit. What does the number <font face="monospace">20738</font> represent?
item.choice: the process ID of the last command executed in the background
the process ID of the echo command
the process ID of the last command executed in the foreground
the process ID of the current shell
item.correct_answer: the process ID of the current shell
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The __________ file maps TCP and UDP ports to service names.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You want the script <font face="monospace">cleanup</font> to be executed each thursday at 04:00. Which of the following crontab entries would you use?
item.hint: The format for a user crontab entry is: minutes, hours, day of month, month, day of week, command. A <font face="monospace">*</font> means every minute, hour, day of month, etc. etc.

item.question: You execute the command <font face="monospace">date +%M</font>. What will the output show you?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You have replaced <font face="monospace">inetd</font> with <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>. What must be done after installation to ensure that your machine will work correctly?
item.choice: You must add a symbolic link from <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>.
You must convert the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to the configuration file format used by <font face="monospace">xinetd</font>.
You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
You must convert and copy the file <font face="monospace">inetd.conf</font> to <font face="monospace">xinetd.conf</font>
item.correct_answer: You don't have to do anything because they are compatible.
item.hint: <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> is backwards compatible with <font face="monospace">inetd</font>. This does not mean that <font face="monospace">xinetd</font> will just read the same configuration files as <font face="monospace">inetd</font> does. However, if you look at the possible choices only one will match this description. Note the direction of the symbolic link that is made in one of the options...

item.question: A new department's local area network has to be connected to an existing LAN using a router. This new department's LAN uses IP addresses from 10.10.1.64/27 and the first two IP addresses there are reserved for the router and a nameserver. How many IP adresses are left for other hosts?
item.hint: Within any network range the address with the host part all zero's or one's cannot be assigned to a network interface in the network. This means that two addresses in the range can not be used. The question states that two valid ip addresses are assigned to the router and a nameserver. Therefore, you will need to subtract 4 from the total amount of addresses in the range.
